title: move index.html response out of static middleware
2.5.9 generates package.json and reports version as 2.5.8
body:
$~ sudo npm -g install express@2.5.9   #or @latest
$~ express -v
2.5.8

$~ express app
$~ cat app/package.json
{
    "name": "application-name"
  , "version": "0.0.1"
  , "private": true
  , "dependencies": {
      "express": "2.5.8"
    , "jade": ">= 0.0.1"
  }

$~ cd /usr/local/lib/node_modules/express
$~ cat package.json
{
  "name": "express",
  "description": "Sinatra inspired web development framework",
  "version": "2.5.9",
  "author": "TJ Holowaychuk tj@vision-media.ca",
[...etc]
$~ cd bin
$~ ./express -v
2.5.8

title: Lazy cookies
body: we should be able to do this in a backwards compatible-ish way, `req.cookies.get(name)` vs `req.cookies.name`, for now we could use getters to unsign / parse json cookies. Getters are lame but at least then we dont have to wait until 4.x for this. The original `res.cookie(name, value[, options])` API would remain, however `req.cookies.set(name, value[, options])` would compliment the `.get()` method using jed's cookie lib(s)

title: express.bodyParser({ ..intended for formidable..}) not assigning listeners
Newline/Paragraph separators not escaped for use in JSONP
API to trigger app.locals.use() middleware execution
body: I'd like to use the app.locals data in places that don't call render() (for example if the response is made with res.json()).  It'd be nice if there was a way to trigger and wait for app.locals.use() middleware to execute independently of calling render().

title: Long running requests - auto retry issue
body:
Hi,
I came across an issue, don't know whether it is the http library of node itself.

What happens is, if there is a request that is taking longer time to process, i see the request gets retried (not from the browser though)...and ends up processing again.

Is this a configuration or something that needs to be set to avoid this ? Any help is appreciated.

Thanks.

title: Adjust dependency version to allow for newer versions of connect, which install with node 0.7.X.
body: More of this. So, I can install `connect` now, using `npm install connect`, but `express` still looks for `connect` version `2.2.1`. This change should be the last required thing to get a simple `npm install express` working with node versions 0.7.X. Dependencies. Sorry, TJ. :(

title: Easy bug fix for JSONP callback when callback contains "[]" ex.: callback=callbacks[123]
body:
https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!topic/express-js/WhhfcQIZgPc

When my callback looks like callbacks[123] it's converted to 
callbacks123 and this leads to an error. I cannot change the code for 
the client because it uses a framework (qooxdoo) which manages by 
itself the jsonp stuff. So this is the problem: 

lib/response.js, Line 139: body = callback.replace(/[^\w$.]/g, '') + 
'(' + body + ');'; 

It's removing the  "[" and "]" when it shouldn't remove them.. 

A fix it's here
ryandesign:
So if this is to be corrected as Totty suggests, and "[" and "]" are to be allowed, then the corrected line would be: 
body = callback.replace(/[^\w$.[]]/g, '') + '(' + body + ');';

title: get port from env in template (fix for #1118)
body: I made a change to the app template as suggested in #1118, that gets the port from an environment variable, if it's present. This is used by multiple deployment environments, including Heroku. The updated app template uses an application setting, `port`, so it can be used elsewhere as well.

title: Is there a way to render just one file without rendering its parents?
parsing + in body forms
body:
I found that form fields containing a space we magically turned into + 

I had to add a regex to fix : 

```
app.post('/library/upload', function(req, res) {  
  var target_path = basedir + querystring.unescape(req.files.file.name).replace(/\+/g);
```

Is this expected behaviour ?

title: add res.locals.use
body:
This is a experimental implementation of feature request [issue 1120](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/1120) which I opened.

I still don't quite understand connect/express ecosystem. As I see in [issure 1000](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/1000) `app.local` is implemented by expando rather than prototype inheritance.

I don't know about javascript performance, but it seems to me that mixining to every response as I implemented is quite inefficient.

title: res.locals.use or res.render async parallel middleware option
Images 404
express scaffolder should support process.env.PORT
body:
Currently the scaffolding tool generates code which listens on PORT 3000. This requites modifying the code to listen to process.env.PORT for deploying to cloud hosting providers.

Suggested change would be to use 

process.env.PORT || 3000

this would allow the code to work locally or in the cloud without having to make a change.

title: overridable view lookup for frameworks
body: with an async signature

title: Made the signature of View.lookup async, and added option to make the lookup function being overridable
body:
This fixes issue [#1089](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/1089).

**Summary of changes:**
- Created a new `lookupView` function in `utils`, which behaves pretty much like the current `View.lookup` method, except it is asynchronous.
- Added a new option `view lookup`, which can be used to replace `utils.lookupView` with a custom function. It expects to be passed a function with the same exact signature as `utils.lookupView`.
- Updated `App.render`, which now passes the lookup function to use to the `View`, in the already-existing options object. Additionally, responsibility to send error message when a view does not exist has been moved to the `View.lookup` method.
- Updated `View.lookup`, whose only responsibility is to call the actual view lookup function passed by `App.render`, and throw an error if not found.
- Updated `View.render`, which now is responsible to call `View.lookup`.
- Also fixes a small indentation problem from my pull request [#1100](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/1100). Sorry about that.

title: Fixed reference to this.body.length in Post validation error when the body length is less than 10 characters
body:
Fixed reference to this.body.length in Post validation error when the body length is less than 10 characters.

This resolves issue #826.

title: package.json: "express" : "*" doesn't install 3.0alpha
body:
So I'm not sure if this is intentional, a bug in npm, or an accident with the version format..

But basically if I specify `"express" : "*"` as the version of express in my `package.json` it won't update to express 3.

To get it to update, I need to explicitly say... `"express" : "3.x"`.

I was pretty confused why it wasn't updating, but if latest is experimental at this point, maybe its best to have wildcard not give you 3.x. Otherwise this might be fixed with `"version" : "3.0.0-alpha1"`, not sure..

title: Migration Wiki Page Errors re https
body:
Hi, the migration from 2->3 page on the wiki seems incorrect in regards to https servers. 

The page states that you can use http.createServer(options,app)  but of course you cannot do so. You have to require('https') and use https.createServer(options,app)

In addition, the app.createServer does not seem to work for https connections.

Regards, Julian.

title: Hogan.js or hulk-hogan or express-hogan or consolidate for 3.x
body:
Hi guys,

I want to use Hogan.js for the templating language in a new 3.x project. However, I don't know which of the libraries to use. Can you help?

So far:
[3.x wiki](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/wiki) says it supports hulk-hogan, but consolidate says it supports Hogan.js...
hulk-hogan also recommends express-hogan which has a few more watchers.

Is there a sample app using 3.x that also uses hogan syntax and partials?

thanks a lot,
Steve

I'm not sure if this is a problem with consolidate or express, but this happens if I'm using any templating engine and consolidate.

title: View.prototype.lookup should be more easily overridable
body:
As of today, changing view lookup behavior requires modifying `View.prototype.lookup`. This looks dirty and, should the API change, not future-proof.

I would suggest adding a configuration option such as `view lookup`, accepting a function to use as a replacement for the default one, if needed.

This would make, for example, view lookup in multiple directories less dirty.

Additionally, it might be better for both performance and functionality (for example, storing views in database) to make the view lookup asynchronous.

I can do a pull request if necessary.

title: res.send should treat String objects as strings, not as objects
body:
The issue title is pretty self-explanatory.

As of today, calling `res.send(new String('foo'))` results in returning a JSON encoded string to the client. In my opinion, it should treat the string object like a string literal, and just return the string.

This is useful, for example, when a template wants to return transparently a compiled template along with meta information, such as individual block contents.

I can do a pull request if necessary.

title: Broken examples
toggle status args back
body:
IMO it's nicer this way:

``` js
res.send(404, 'Sorry not found')
```

but the old way is:

``` js
res.send('Sorry not found', 404);
```

ultimately it doesn't really matter haha so probably best to switch back

title: Connect 1.8.7 throwing error
body:
``` javascript
ReferenceError: utils is not defined
    at next (~/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:172:48)
    at pass (~/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:219:24)
    at nextRoute (~/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:209:7)
    at callbacks (~/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:274:11)
```

Our npm deployed code started throwing this error just minutes ago. It would be great if express could reference an exact version of connect to avoid surprises like this!

title: how to get # fragments of a url.
body:
Sorry for asking this question here but I could not find how to get hash part of a request url. 

e.g. 

http://sample.com/#test

where in the req object the #test is stored?

Thanks.

title: Update to commander 0.6.0
body:
npm install commander@0.5.2 fails with

```
npm ERR! Error: ENOENT, open '/Users/shinuza/tmp/node_modules/commander/package.json'
```

npm install commander@0.6.0 works, depending if 0.6.0 is backwards compatible this pull request might be required to install commander (at least the git up version)

title: Add protocol to fix link being interpreted as relative in README.md.
body: Minor fix for an minor problem: the link to Consolidate.js was busted because it was being treated as relative.

title: Object function app(req, res){ app.handle(req, res); } has no method 'register'
body:
So after downloading the MVC example and running:

```
cd mvc/ && npm install express ejs
```

When I go to run node app.js I receive the following:

```
node.js:201
    throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
          ^
TypeError: Object function app(req, res){ app.handle(req, res); } has no method 'register'
```

If I comment out line 37 to:

```
//app.register('.html', require('ejs'));
```

I then get the following error:

```
node.js:201
    throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
          ^
    TypeError: Object function app(req, res){ app.handle(req, res); } has no method 'dynamicHelpers'
```

```
app.get('/:username',function(req,res){

title: ejs example out of date
body:
In express/examples/ejs/index.js

``` javascript
app.engine('.html', require('ejs').__express);
```

Should be probably be...

``` javascript
app.register('.html', require('ejs'));
```

title: cannot call method 'load' of undefined
body:
Hi all,

I am trying to following TJ's comment here: http://www.danielbaulig.de/socket-ioexpress/#comment-2705

However, I don't think store is defined for my app. 

I am using express@2.5.9 with connect@1.8.6 and node v0.6.10

detailed error here: 

/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/flockwire.com/realtime.js:18
    app.store.load(sid, function(err, sess){
              ^
TypeError: Cannot call method 'load' of undefined
    at Manager.<anonymous> (/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/proj/realtime.js:18:15)
    at Manager.authorize (/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/node_modules/socket.io/lib/manager.js:866:31)
    at Manager.handleHandshake (/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/node_modules/socket.io/lib/manager.js:742:8)
    at Manager.handleRequest (/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/node_modules/socket.io/lib/manager.js:569:12)
    at HTTPServer.<anonymous> (/mnt/hgfs/Dropbox/projects/node_modules/socket.io/lib/manager.js:115:10)
    at HTTPServer.emit (events.js:70:17)
    at HTTPParser.onIncoming (http.js:1511:12)
    at HTTPParser.onHeadersComplete (http.js:102:31)
    at Socket.ondata (http.js:1407:22)
    at TCP.onread (net.js:354:27)

Thanks a lot for any help :)

Jason

title: Adding support back in for less CSS.
body: Added support back in for the `--css` flag since there is now a less middleware for less compilation.

title: The guide says that `res.contentType` can accept literal types. This makes that true.
body: I mentioned in the comments for #1047 that this will break code that does `res.contentType('path/foo.blagh')` with the expectation that they will get the fallback type `application/octet-stream` but I think that's an acceptable tradeoff.

title: manpage
body: yup

title: Jade mixins need locals to access vars in jade 0.22.1
body:
I went from Jade 0.21.0 to jade 0.22.1 and noticed that locals don't work unless you explicitly call locals.var. Not sure if this is a bug or if it's intentional.

Created a test app that shows the problem:

https://github.com/Enome/Jade-Bug-Explicit-locals-in-mixins/blob/master/views/mixins.jade

I can do a pull request if desired.

title: Unused require of fs module
body: Looks like File System module usage had been refactored out of view.js some time ago, but the require remained.

title: View lookup should return something at least
body:
Even if the path doesn't exist it's better for the lookup
method to return the last path checked. Without a return
value, if one attempts to render a path that doesn't
exist one gets "TypeError: Bad argument" because the
first param for fs.readFile is undefined. If the path is
returned one gets the more helpful "Error: ENOENT, no
such file or directory" along with the string for the
path.

title: (trivial) Give express init middleware function an explicit name
body:
Middleware stack printout before:
    NODE> app.stack
    [ { route: '', handle: [Function: query] },
      { route: '', handle: [Function] },
      { route: '', handle: [Function: favicon] },
      { route: '', handle: [Function: logger] },

```
Middleware stack printout after:
NODE> app.stack
[ { route: '', handle: [Function: query] },
  { route: '', handle: [Function: expressInit] },
  { route: '', handle: [Function: favicon] },
  { route: '', handle: [Function: logger] },
```

title: app.get middleware should support error handlers.
Explicitly render a string of HTML or markdown in Jade
body:
Hey everyone, I want to render some HTML in a Jade view which was passed through a variable. It is currently rendering as escaped HTML and not plain HTML, how do I go about explicitly rendering it as plain HTML? I understand it may be a bad security practice but what if it is plain markdown text that gets converted to HTML at render time? ``` // in the route res.render('index', { title: 'Lorem Ipsum', article: '

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

' }); // jade view h1= title #{article} ``` The current output: ```

Lorem Ipsum

<p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.</p> ``` I would like it to be rendered as: ```

Lorem Ipsum

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

``` Markdown scenario: ``` // in the route res.render('index', { title: 'Lorem Ipsum', article: md('Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.') }); ``` I would like it to be rendered as: ```

Lorem Ipsum

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

```

title: Render with layout.html in 3.0.0 (workaround)
format should accept patterns
body: Using the same format method for multiple formats is ugly. We should accept patterns or lists as keys. Lists make more sense, but are probably uglier. I can implement this if you'd like. Just let me know if/what you would accept.

title: Adds best match feature to req.accepts
body:
Rebased against latest master and commits squashed.

This replaces https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/1052

title: Adds acceptBestMatch to request
body: Given an Array of mime types ordered by server preference, this function will return the best match according for the Accept header, taking the quality parameter into account.

title: Cannot delete cookies
Returning application/json instead of text/plain for router errors
body:
Is there any way to intercept routing errors to return the proper formet for JSON APIs?

right now, a `text/plain` response like this is sent:

```
Cannot PUT /
```

but I'd rather have something more appropriate in `application/json`, like this:

``` json
{
  "error": "error",
  "message": "Cannot PUT /"
}
```

title: [feature] Introduce context for req/res cycle.
body:
It seems that by introducing optional context object for req/res cycle it 
would be possible to write more terse code.

Right now we must pass req/res to every callback:

```
setUser = (req, res, next) ->
  req.user = {name: 'Anonymous'}
  next()
app.use setUser

app.get '/', (req, res) ->
  res.end "Hello, #{req.user.name}"
```

But, it seems that this may be simplified if we create context object 
for every request and evaluate every callback within this context:

```
setUser = ->
  @user = {name: 'Anonymous'}
  @next()
app.use setUser

app.get '/', ->
  @res.end "Hello, #{@user.name}"
```

Old code also should works the same as before.

What do You think?

title: Access to protocol
body: Is there any way to get access to the protocol of the current request. I have looked at req.headers.referer but that doesn't seem to work. I need it to determine if the upstream proxy request was made over ssl.

title: Do not lie about what res.contentType() accepts
body:
Passing it a literal content type string will not always work. For
`application/json` it works only by pure chance. It is because `json` is also
coincidentally the file extension. But if you tried `application/javascript`
it would set the content type header to `application/octet-stream`, because
`javascript` is not a known file extension.

FIXME: do I have to regenerate the html docs or can you do that for me?

title: Updated Readme and screencast.md
Session regeneration and user
body:
I was consulting the examples and various other source codes and saw that upon authentication, the best practice is to "regenerate" the session before setting the user. Is there behavior change on this by any chance?

This is the gist of the code I tried to ran modified one of the gists in another discussion: https://gist.github.com/2018853

The expected result would be as follow:
    /login -> user input "test"
    / -> test

The actual results is as follow:
    /login -> user input "test"
    / -> none

I expect the req.session.user to persist in the new session but it seems to me like after the redirection, another new session is regenerated and session.user is lost (undefined). I'm not sure if this is by design or a known behavior. The user variable however will stay if I do not regenerate the session.
